unnormalised: Okay, here is the generated blog post based on your provided parameters:
normalised: **Subject: Chai Breaks and Chaos: A Week in My W-F-H Life**

unnormalised: **Subject: Chai Breaks and Chaos: A Week in My WFH Life**
normalised: Okay, so my attempts at a "structured" W-F-H life? Let's just say they're a work in progress. It all started with the best intentions, really. I envisioned waking up at six thirty A-M sharp, meditating for thirty minutes (thanks, Headspace!), and then diving headfirst into work by seven thirty A-M. The reality? Snooze button city until at least eight fifteen A-M. Some habits die hard, even when your commute is literally from the bed to the desk.

unnormalised: Okay, so my attempts at a "structured" WFH life? Let's just say they're a work in progress. It all started with the best intentions, really. I envisioned waking up at 6:30 AM sharp, meditating for 30 minutes (thanks, Headspace!), and then diving headfirst into work by 7:30 AM. The reality? Snooze button city until at least 8:15 AM. Some habits die hard, even when your commute is literally from the bed to the desk.
normalised: Monday, or rather, what was *supposed* to be Monday, began with a power cut. Scheduled, of course, but still! I had a crucial client call at nine A-M, and naturally, the electricity decided to take a vacation precisely at eight fifty eight A-M. Cue frantic tethering to my phone's hotspot, praying the connection would hold. It didn't. Rescheduled for eleven A-M. Lost a good half-hour trying to explain to the client that "bijli chali gayi" isn't a valid business excuse everywhere in the world.

unnormalised: Monday, or rather, what was *supposed* to be Monday, began with a power cut. Scheduled, of course, but still! I had a crucial client call at 9:00 AM, and naturally, the electricity decided to take a vacation precisely at 8:58 AM. Cue frantic tethering to my phone's hotspot, praying the connection would hold. It didn’t. Rescheduled for 11:00 AM. Lost a good half-hour trying to explain to the client that "bijli chali gayi" isn't a valid business excuse everywhere in the world.
normalised: Tuesday was the day I tried to prepone a meeting because I had a doctor's appointment. I emailed my team lead asking if we could shift the three P-M huddle to one thirty P-M. Got a reply saying "Sure, if everyone's okay with it." Everyone wasn't. So, I juggled a slightly uncomfortable but thankfully brief consultation with Doctor Sharma, followed by racing back home to dial into the meeting at three zero seven P-M, already feeling frazzled. Note to self: Never prepone, only postpone.

unnormalised: Tuesday was the day I tried to prepone a meeting because I had a doctor's appointment. I emailed my team lead asking if we could shift the 3:00 PM huddle to 1:30 PM. Got a reply saying "Sure, if everyone's okay with it." Everyone wasn't. So, I juggled a slightly uncomfortable but thankfully brief consultation with Dr. Sharma, followed by racing back home to dial into the meeting at 3:07 PM, already feeling frazzled. Note to self: Never prepone, only postpone.
normalised: Wednesday was relatively smooth, thankfully. Just the usual interruptions. A delivery guy at ten forty five A-M wanting a signature for something I didn't order. Mom calling at twelve fifteen P-M sharp to ask if I'd eaten lunch (because apparently, I can't be trusted to feed myself). The neighbor's dog barking incessantly during a presentation at two P-M. The joys of working from “home”.

unnormalised: Wednesday was relatively smooth, thankfully. Just the usual interruptions. A delivery guy at 10:45 AM wanting a signature for something I didn’t order. Mom calling at 12:15 PM sharp to ask if I’d eaten lunch (because apparently, I can’t be trusted to feed myself). The neighbor’s dog barking incessantly during a presentation at 2:00 PM. The joys of working from “home”.
normalised: Thursday was almost disastrous. I had completely blanked on a deadline. It was supposed to be submitted by five P-M, and I remembered it only at four fifteen P-M. A frantic hour and some very strong chai later, I managed to submit it just in the nick of time at four fifty eight P-M. My stress levels hit a new high. Maybe I should start using a physical planner instead of relying on Google Calendar.

unnormalised: Thursday was almost disastrous. I had completely blanked on a deadline. It was supposed to be submitted by 5:00 PM, and I remembered it only at 4:15 PM. A frantic hour and some very strong chai later, I managed to submit it just in the nick of time at 4:58 PM. My stress levels hit a new high. Maybe I should start using a physical planner instead of relying on Google Calendar.
normalised: Friday started out normal enough. I had a team call at ten A-M. Then came the bombshell. My boss decided to have a surprise team-building activity that would stretch from eleven thirty A-M to two thirty P-M. I'm like, "surprise team-building on a Friday? Seriously?". Well, that cut deep into what was planned as a chill day.

unnormalised: Friday started out normal enough. I had a team call at 10:00 AM. Then came the bombshell. My boss decided to have a surprise team-building activity that would stretch from 11:30 AM to 2:30 PM. I'm like, "surprise team-building on a Friday? Seriously?". Well, that cut deep into what was planned as a chill day.
normalised: Saturday, I was planning on relaxing and watching a movie in the afternoon. But no! My supervisor called me at eleven A-M, requesting some urgent assistance. Of course, I couldn't say no, especially after almost missing the deadline on Thursday.

unnormalised: Saturday, I was planning on relaxing and watching a movie in the afternoon. But no! My supervisor called me at 11:00 AM, requesting some urgent assistance. Of course, I couldn't say no, especially after almost missing the deadline on Thursday.
normalised: So, here I am, Sunday night, feeling like I need a vacation from my work-from-home routine. Maybe I should apply for a full-time on-site job. One can only hope, right? At least the chai breaks are good.

unnormalised: So, here I am, Sunday night, feeling like I need a vacation from my work-from-home routine. Maybe I should apply for a full-time on-site job. One can only hope, right? At least the chai breaks are good.
